updates.update_content:
Well, that’s a wrap! 

 I thank you all for your pledges and your active tweeting, facebook posting and other word-of-mouth type efforts. (We'll get it done next time!) 
For those of you who phrased your social media support in terms of “Ken/Nix Comics really deserves this,” I am particularly humbled by your estimations. I will do my best in the coming years to live up to your expectations.

For those of you who haven't been following my facebook and twitter posts, I wanted to let you know that I've taken a brief break in the kickstarter action to help support an institution that I count as one of my biggest influences: Norton Records. (Their Brooklyn warehouse was nearly obliterated by Hurricane Sandy.  Read about it here: http://nortonville.blogspot.com/)
Norton is currently asking for donations to help rebuild their stock, primarily picture sleeves for the 1,000s of 45s that they were able to salvage.  I want to contribute, but like all comic self-publishers, I don't exactly have a lot of money on hand.  So, in an attempt to raise some cash to help the label that introduced me to the likes of the Real Kids, Andre Williams and Untamed Youth I'm making the following offer:  All sales from the Nix Comics Website will be donated to Nortn Records rebuild efforts.  Please pass it on!

One of the great things about this new super-ambitious Kickstarter is the number of new fans Nix is picking up.  Whether I reach my goal or not, I feel like I've been put in touch with a lot of cool people!
That being the case, though, it might be time to reintroduce myself and Nix Comics to the world.  My name is Ken Eppstein and I'm both a comic book and Rock-n-Roll record lover.  (The first record and comic book I can remember buying with my own money was a single package! I bought one of those power records at a Modell's department store on Long Island; a comic reprint of the origin of the Fantastic Four with a narrative 45rpm record that made a shrill "ding" noise when it was time to turn the page. It cemented the connection in my pre-teen mind.)

I think that the two Original Artwork rewards that I'm offering this campaign are my favorite rewards.  It has been really flattering that artists of the caliber of Michael Neno and Andy Bennett have been willing to work with me on Nix Comics!  This is your chance to get a set of collectibles from two exciting artists, get a subscription to one of the coolest indie pubs going and put a little cash in all of pockets.  
(That's right!  Most of the money from this reward will go directly to Andy and/or Michael!  I takes care of my peeps!)

HELP US REACH OUR NEW STRETCH GOAL OF $42K!
Thank you so much for the support you've given "Salad Days" and for helping reach our initial goal. However, we've set a new goal now with the time remaining. We've also added a new reward! 
On December 28, at the Black Cat in Washington, DC we'll be hosting an event to end all events! DC punk legends Dag Nasty (original line-up), Government Issue, Black Market Baby and Kingface will all play together to celebrate the filming of "Salad Days." See below for a limited set of tickets! 
Remember, every dollar that is pledged beyond this point will go towards making "Salad Days" the best possible film it can be—it's a subject we're passionate about and we know you are, too! 
Thank you, really.
Scott Crawford
Jim Saah
ABOUT THE MOVIE
SALAD DAYS  is a documentary-in-progress that examines the fertile Washington, DC punk scene of the 1980s. This was a particularly important time in the evolution of punk and independent music, with DC based bands like Minor Threat, Bad Brains, Black Market Baby, the Faith, the Slickee Boys, Void, Government Issue, Marginal Man, Dag Nasty, 9353, Gray Matter, Beefeater, Scream, Rites of Spring, Fugazi, Shudder to Think, Nation of Ulysses, Jawbox and others defining the DC aesthetic. Local record labels like Dischord, Fountain of Youth, Teen Beat, and Simple Machines would become standard-bearers for the DIY revolution. 

WHY NOW
Much has been written about the pre-Nirvana period of American punk
rock, but there's never been an examination of DC's 
contribution. We've spent the last year interviewing dozens of
the participants who helped create the local music scene in the 1980s— musicians, photographers, DJs, activists, and writers—to tell the story of one of the most inspiring (and misunderstood) decades in independent music. We've also sorted through hundreds of photos, live videos, flyers and zines for inclusion in the film.
Like countless others, I discovered punk rock as a kid. Growing up in the Washington, DC area I was so taken with what I was witnessing that I started a fanzine and began to document the local scene. Almost 30 years later, I wanted to revisit the people and places that have informed my life and so many others. It's been a hell of a journey so far—but we're not done yet.
WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP
As we finish up the pre-production phase, we need your help. Your donations will offset the upcoming costs of editing, animation, graphics, mastering, color correction, sound editing, travel and more. We have a daunting task ahead of us—and yet we’re so passionate about telling this story that we’re anxious to share it with the world as soon as we can. We hope SALAD DAYS will see a Q3 2013 release and we have high hopes for its festival run. Thanks in advance for your support—we can’t do it without you!
With Ian MacKaye during his interview for SALAD DAYS.
With Dave Grohl during the filming of SALAD DAYS
WHO WE ARE
An August 1985 Washington City Paper article on Crawford entitled "Punktrepeneur"...
SALAD DAYS Director/writer SCOTT CRAWFORD is a music journalist, musician and graphic designer. As a teenager in the DC suburbs, he started a fanzine called Metrozine that documented much of what was happening in the DC hardcore punk scene in the 1980s. In 1985, Metrozine (and WGNS) released a 7" compilation called "Alive & Kicking" that featured unreleased tracks by DC area bands Gray Matter, United Mutation, Marginal Man, Beefeater, Cereal Killer and Mission Impossible (featuring a 16 year old Dave Grohl). He was quoted in both Dance of Days and Banned in DC—the two most definitive books on the early DC punk scene. In 2001, he launched Harp magazine and served as its Editor-in-Chief for over 7 years. Crawford also launched the online music portal Blurt (blurt-online.com) in 2009.
Serving as Director of Photography for SALAD DAYS, Jim Saah (jimsaah.com) is a native of Washington, DC who has worked professionally in photography and video for over 25 years. He has shot for a variety of publications and websites ranging from the Washington Post to Rolling Stone.
He's also an experienced videographer whose credits range from union organizing films to music documentaries. Recent films he has worked on include movies about the bands Wilco, Death Cab for Cutie and Eddie Vedder.
HOW KICKSTARTER WORKS
Kickstarter is an amazing funding platform for creative projects like ours. However, it's an all or nothing process—if we don't reach our goal, we lose EVERYTHING. We've given ourselves 30 days to fund this project. Please help us in any way you can. We have something for everyone—regardless of how much you give. 
CAN WE EXCEED OUR GOAL?
Absolutely! Every penny we receive is going towards making the best film we can possibly make. Therefore, anything we can make beyond or goal can be put towards covering all of the many unexpected costs that will no doubt occur along the way. 
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!
Scott Crawford
Director/writer SALAD DAYS

MAGIC BULLET is the premier comic newspaper of the Washington, D.C.  Situated in the nation's capital, MAGIC BULLET showcases the work of independent and underground cartoonists throughout the DC metro area, giving them an entire page of the newspaper and encouraging them to cut loose, experiment and push their comics as far as they can.   MAGIC BULLET is published semi-annually and is completely free.  Over four issues, MAGIC BULLET has steadily increased in scope, more than doubling its page count (up to almost 30 pages!) and now being distributed, literally, from coast to coast: it can be found in comic shops and stores in the greater Washington, DC area, as well as stores across the country and into California.  It is also distributed at comic conventions such as DC’s Small Press Expo, the Baltimore Comic-Con and many others.  In 2011, MAGIC BULLET became part of the holdings of the Library of Congress, as part of the Small Press Expo’s contributions of indie comics. 
http://magicbulletcomics.com/

campaign.story:
“The only thing we have to fear is fear itself… and ZOMBIES!!”   -Franklin Delano Roosevelt
 The 35 Small-Press Commandos that contributed to FUBAR: Empire of Rising Dead need your help getting this anthology to the printer!  In return for your hard earned money, we offer graphic novels, custom artwork, zombie shooting targets AND our unwavering gratitude.
Hello! My name is Jeff McComsey and I’m the editor in chief of the World War II zombie anthology called FUBAR.
This anthology chronicles a zombie outbreak right in the middle of World War II, just prior to the d-day invasion. Originally FUBAR started out as a small side project of mine and like side projects tend to do, it took on a life of its own and then took over mine.
We released our first 188 page volume last year Entitled FUBAR: European theater of the Damned. We set the 15 stories of volume one in the European theater of WWII. Classic zombie Nazi smashing fun for the whole family in that volume.
The 20 stories that comprise FUBAR volume 2: Empire of the Rising Dead all take place exclusively in the Pacific theater of World War II.  Replace zombie Nazis with Zombie Kamikazes and add in a helping of crazy zombie Jarheads and you get the idea.
Both volumes are stand alone and don't need to be read in order so choose whichever volume strikes your World War II zombie smashing fancy... OR you could get both.
FUBAR VOLUME 1 PREVIEW!
FUBAR VOLUME 2 PREVIEW!
Volume 2 clocks in at 194 pages and contains the work of over 35 writers, artists, letterers, and is 100% complete and ready to go.
The logistics are all locked in except for one important part. We're here  to ask you ladies and gents for a little help getting this second volume off to the  printer.
 If funding is successful we intend to use the money exclusively for the offset print run of FUBAR Volume 2: Empire of the rising Dead.  
 CUSTOM SKETCHES!
There's a lot of the custom art and sketching we only ever get to do at conventions and signings like: our choose your own historical/fictitious WW II character and we draw them in the front page square of your newly purchased book sketch.  We're very excited about sharing these type of pledge rewards with any supporters who purchase Volume 1 or Volume 2.
AND ZOMBIE SHOOTING TARGETS?
Below you will find links to examples of some of our pledge rewards including a gallery of Steve Becker's Zombie Combat targets that you get to choose from for those specific rewards featuring an 11x17 print. You will also find links to view some of the custom zombie sketches we do in the front pages of both Volume 1 and 2. We've also included links to the zombie portraits and the Medal of Honor portrait so you guys get a better idea of what we mean in the pledge rewards.
ZOMBIE COMBAT TARGETS
CUSTOM FRONT SKETCHES
ZOMBIE PORTRAITS
MEDAL OF HONOR PORTRAITS
SIX PANEL CINEMA
You guys are awesome...
In the comics community there's always talk about whether or not the medium's day has come and gone. Looking around at the caliber of new creators and projects In the Small-Press community alone as well as remarkable outlets like Kickstarter, We feel like there's never been a better time to make comics.
 This series contains inspired work by over three dozen writers, artists, letterers and is to date the project of which I am most proud to have been a part of.  Your support of Indie comics in general and FUBAR in particular makes it possible for these project to exist and thrive. I know I can speak for all the creators involved when I say thank you. Thanks you for your time and for your support.

Hey everyone,
We here at the DC Conspiracy hope that you enjoyed MAGIC BULLET #2 and once again thank you for supporting that project.
We are sending out this quick note to let you know that we are now raising funds for MAGIC BULLET #3 on Kickstarter. We've got a bunch of new prizes for pledging, including the easiest way for you to get your hands on a copy of the upcoming issue.

Hi everyone,
This should be the last update for MAGIC BULLET #2 so first let me thank you all once again. The last of the pledge prizes were sent out earlier this week so you all should be getting your packages soon.
News: On Monday, March 28th, members of the DC Conspiracy handed out between 500 and 1000 copies of MAGIC BULLET to morning DC commuters. Some folks were confused, some were scared, but the ones who took papers seemed pretty happy.
We have also been dropping the papers of at various local (and not so local) comics shops and other places. An incomplete, but constantly updated map of MAGIC BULLET sightings can be found here: http://bit.ly/hFAfls

As the MAGIC BULLET fundraiser ended successfully about half an hour ago, I thought I would take this time to thank all of you who made this possible.
The paper itself is 90% complete and will be ready to be sent to the printer once the Kickstarter funds transfer. Once those are in hand, I will start sending out prizes.
I will do my best to keep everyone in the loop, but if you have any questions feel free to email me or post a message on the project board.

updates.update_content:
First of all, I would like to thank each and every one of you who pledged money to MAGIC BULLET helping us to reach our goal. Going in to this I was worried about whether this fundraiser would be successful, whether anyone would be receptive enough to the idea to want to give money to help us out, and whether as we got close to the end of the fundraising timeframe I would be begging people for money. You folks make me feel silly for worrying at all.
You are all super awesome, and I cannot thank you enough.

Hi everyone,
We're only a week in to the fundraising and it looks like we are over 50% of the way to our goal. This is fantastic, and I want to thank all of you who have already pledged. So, thank you.
Over the next few weeks I plan on updating this page with artwork from MAGIC BULLET #2, so even if you have already pledged, please check back to see some of the fine comics you have helped to support.
